content: Currently I'm stuck at telling Lean to calculate the derivative of implicit functions.
Can you post the code which defines the function you want to differentiate?
Sure. This is the file I'm working, but I haven't define the final implicit function yet. test001.lean
The idea of proof of problem 2 in that file is not quite correct (which tries to avoid differentiating implicit functions), and I have to revert to the human-readable proof now.
Oops. It looks like that the post containing the problem description itself is failed to send. I'm sorry. Will try to repost as soon as possible.

The problem description:

Let a,b,t∈Ra,b,t\in\mathbb{R}a,b,t∈R be positive such that a≠ba\neq ba=b, a=tb3a=tb^3a=tb3, and aa=bba^a=b^baa=bb.
(1) If t=4t=4t=4, prove that 1/e+4/e3<a+b<11/e+4/e^3 < a+b < 11/e+4/e3<a+b<1.
(2) Assume moreover that a+b>2/ta+b>2/\sqrt{t}a+b>2/t​. View a,ba,ba,b as functions of ttt and denote g(t)=a+bg(t)=a+bg(t)=a+b.
Compute the range of ttt and prove that g(t)g(t)g(t) increases as ttt increases.

The solution to problem 1:

Let y=f(x)=xlog⁡xy=f(x)=x \log xy=f(x)=xlogx for x>0x>0x>0, then f(x)<0f(x)<0f(x)<0 when x<1x<1x<1, f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0 when x=1x=1x=1, and f(x)>0f(x)>0f(x)>0 when x>1x>1x>1.
We have f′(x)=1+log⁡xf'(x)=1+\log xf′(x)=1+logx, which satisfies f′(x)<0f'(x)<0f′(x)<0 when x<1/ex<1/ex<1/e, and f′(x)>0f'(x)>0f′(x)>0 when x>1/ex>1/ex>1/e.
Therefore f(x)f(x)f(x) decreases as xxx increases if x∈(0,1/e)x\in(0,1/e)x∈(0,1/e), f(x)f(x)f(x) increases as xxx increases if x∈(1/e,+∞)x\in(1/e, +\infty)x∈(1/e,+∞), and f(x)f(x)f(x) takes minimun at x=1/ex=1/ex=1/e with value −1/e-1/e−1/e.
Therefore if a≠ba\neq ba=b such that aa=bba^a=b^baa=bb, then f(a)=f(b)=:yf(a)=f(b)=:yf(a)=f(b)=:y, we must have y∈(−1/e,0)y\in(-1/e,0)y∈(−1/e,0), a,b∈(0,1/e)∪(1/e,1)a,b\in(0,1/e)\cup(1/e,1)a,b∈(0,1/e)∪(1/e,1), and

  • bbb decreases and ttt increases as aaa increases,
  • either a∈(0,1/e),b∈(1/e,1),t∈(0,e2)a\in(0,1/e),b\in(1/e,1),t\in(0,e^2)a∈(0,1/e),b∈(1/e,1),t∈(0,e2), or a∈(1/e,1),b∈(0,1/e),t∈(e2,+∞)a\in(1/e,1),b\in(0,1/e),t\in(e^2,+\infty)a∈(1/e,1),b∈(0,1/e),t∈(e2,+∞).
  • If a>ba > ba>b, then 1/t=b3/a<b3/b=b1/\sqrt{t}=\sqrt{b^3/a} < \sqrt{b^3/b}=b1/t​=b3/a​<b3/b​=b and hence a+b>2b>2/ta+b > 2b > 2/\sqrt{t}a+b>2b>2/t​.
  • If a<ba < ba<b, then 1/t=b3/a>b3/b=b1/\sqrt{t}=\sqrt{b^3/a} > \sqrt{b^3/b}=b1/t​=b3/a​>b3/b​=b and hence a+b<2b<2/ta+b < 2b < 2/\sqrt{t}a+b<2b<2/t​.

The (1) comes from that since t=4<e2t=4 < e^2t=4<e2, we have a<1/e<ba < 1/e < ba<1/e<b,
hence a+b<2/t=1a+b < 2/\sqrt{t}=1a+b<2/t​=1 and a+b=tb3+b>t/e3+1/e=1/e+4/e3a+b=tb^3+b>t/e^3+1/e=1/e+4/e^3a+b=tb3+b>t/e3+1/e=1/e+4/e3.

The solution to problem 2:

It's clear from the above discussion that the range of ttt is (e2,+∞)(e^2,+\infty)(e2,+∞).
Conversely, when aaa goes up from 1/e1/e1/e to 111 the bbb goes down from 1/e1/e1/e to 000, and the ttt goes up from e2e^2e2 to +∞+\infty+∞, hence given any t>e2t>e^2t>e2 there exist a,ba,ba,b which satisfy the desired conditions.

Since ttt increases as aaa increases, we only need to show that ggg increases as aaa increases, namely d(a+b)/da>0\mathrm{d}(a+b)/\mathrm{d}a>0d(a+b)/da>0.
We have d(a+b)/da=1+db/da=1+(dy/da)/(dy/db)=1+(1+log⁡a)/(1+log⁡b)\mathrm{d}(a+b)/\mathrm{d}a=1+\mathrm{d}b/\mathrm{d}a=1+(\mathrm{d}y/\mathrm{d}a)/(\mathrm{d}y/\mathrm{d}b)=1+(1+\log a)/(1+\log b)d(a+b)/da=1+db/da=1+(dy/da)/(dy/db)=1+(1+loga)/(1+logb).
Since 1+log⁡b<01+\log b<01+logb<0, we only need to show log⁡b+log⁡a+2<0\log b+\log a+2<0logb+loga+2<0, namely ab<1/e2ab<1/e^2ab<1/e2, namely b<1/ae2b<1/ae^2b<1/ae2.
Since b<1/eb<1/eb<1/e and 1/ae2<1/e1/ae^2<1/e1/ae2<1/e, this is equivalent to f(b)>f(1/ae2)f(b)>f(1/ae^2)f(b)>f(1/ae2), namely alog⁡a>1ae2(−2−log⁡a)a \log a > \frac{1}{ae^2}(-2-\log a)aloga>ae21​(−2−loga), note that f(a)=f(b)f(a)=f(b)f(a)=f(b).
This is equivalent to g(x)>0g(x)>0g(x)>0 for x∈(1/e,1)x\in(1/e,1)x∈(1/e,1), where g(x)=(x+1xe2)log⁡x+2xe2g(x)=\left(x+\frac{1}{xe^2}\right)\log x + \frac{2}{xe^2}g(x)=(x+xe21​)logx+xe22​.
Since g(1/e)=0g(1/e)=0g(1/e)=0, we only need to show that g′(x)>0g'(x)>0g′(x)>0 for x∈(1/e,1)x\in(1/e,1)x∈(1/e,1).
This is true since g′(x)=...=(1−1x2e2)(1+log⁡x)g'(x)= ... = \left(1-\frac{1}{x^2e^2}\right)(1+\log x)g′(x)=...=(1−x2e21​)(1+logx), which is obviously positive if x∈(1/e,1)x\in(1/e,1)x∈(1/e,1).
Currently I finished formalizing the proof of problem 1, and working on problem 2. I'm wondering that how to tell Lean to calculate the implicit derivative d(b)/da\mathrm{d}(b)/\mathrm{d}ad(b)/da.
@Jz Pan mathlib has the implicit function theorem: docs#has_strict_fderiv_at.implicit_function. It's phrased very abstractly, but in principle, the result you need can be deduced from this.
